g.text: Copper composite at 700 K, the improvement in the
for composite with SnSe single crystal component was as much as
51% compared to composite with isotropic SnSe polycrystal components. For the In
composite, the single-crystal form of In
had anisotropic Seebeck properties, but there are no
ective properties of polycrystals with anisotropic Seebeck properties.
Therefore, the comparison on the cooling performances for the In
composites with isotropic and anisotropic In
This study investigated the transverse thermoelectric properties of ﬁbrous composites with
anisotropic component materials. A mathematical model was built for predicting the transverse
ectiveness of the mathematical model was veriﬁed by ﬁnite element simulations. The agreement
among the two approaches indicated that the mathematical model can serve as an e
selecting and screening prospecting candidates for ﬁbrous transverse thermoelectric composites with
anisotropic material components. A case study using anisotropic Bi
isotropic Copper as the ﬁber was performed and a
values for both the layered and ﬁbrous transverse
thermoelectric composites was investigated with respect to the possible anisotropic properties of
component phase. The results showed that by enhancing the anisotropic proﬁle of polycrystal,
for both the layered and ﬁbrous transverse thermoelectric composites
can be improved. For the SnSe
Copper composite at 700 K, the improvement of maximumZ
values for the composite with anisotropic SnSe single-crystal components can be as much as
51%compared to the composites with isotropic SnSe polycrystals.
This study also showed that the alignment of the component’s local property axes in the composite
can lead to signiﬁcant variance in the Z
values of the composite. For the Bi
erence in the thermoelectric performance caused by the alignment of the anisotropic
component’s property axis was 50%. For the SnSe
This discrepancy was mainly caused by the variance in the anisotropic properties among di
material property axis directions in the component phase.
Conceptualization, B.Q. and F.R.; methodology, B.Q.; software, F.W.; validation, B.Q., Y.Z.
and T.W.; writing—original draft preparation, B.Q.; writing—review and editing, F.R., Y.Z. and T.W.; funding
This research was funded by the Central South University and Temple University.
The authors declare no conﬂict of interest.
